message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a fast heart rate, a grade III holosystolic murmur, and the ECG findings suggest Ebstein anomaly. Pulmonic stenosis and Tetralogy of Fallot have different murmurs, and Tricuspid atresia does not produce a murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fast heart rate and the grade III holosystolic murmur suggest Ebstein anomaly, which is characterized by the displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle. The short P-R interval and slow upstroke of the QRS complex are also common findings in this condition. The other options would present with different clinical features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fast heart rate and the holosystolic murmur suggest Ebstein anomaly. The short P-R interval and slow upstroke of the QRS complex on ECG are also consistent with this diagnosis. Pulmonic stenosis would present with a systolic ejection murmur, Tricuspid atresia with a silent right ventricle, and Tetralogy of Fallot with a harsh systolic ejection murmur and cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fast heart rate and the grade III holosystolic murmur suggest Ebstein anomaly, which is associated with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, explaining the short P-R interval and slow QRS complex upstroke. Other options would present with different symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and signs suggest Ebstein anomaly, which causes tachycardia, a grade III holosystolic murmur, and ECG changes such as a short P-R interval and a slow upstroke of the QRS complex. Pulmonic stenosis causes a systolic ejection murmur, while tricuspid atresia and Tetralogy of Fallot would present with cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of fast heartbeats, holosystolic murmur, and ECG findings of a short P-R interval with a slow upstroke of the QRS complex are most consistent with Ebstein anomaly. Pulmonic stenosis presents with a systolic ejection murmur, tricuspid atresia would result in a complete lack of a tricuspid valve (and thus no murmur), and tetralogy of Fallot presents with a systolic ejection murmur and cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest Ebstein anomaly, which is characterized by a holosystolic murmur, a short P-R interval, and a slow upstroke of the QRS complex. Pulmonic stenosis would present with a harsh systolic ejection murmur. Tricuspid atresia would present with a very soft or absent heart sound on the right side of the chest. Tetralogy of Fallot would present with a harsh holosystolic murmur and an abnormal QRS complex, but with a prolonged P-R interval rather than a short one.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The short P-R interval and slow upstroke of QRS complex on ECG suggest WPW syndrome. Among the options, Ebstein anomaly is associated with WPW syndrome, and can present with a holosystolic murmur. The other options are not associated with WPW syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with fast heartbeats, a holosystolic murmur, and a short P-R interval with a slow upstroke of the QRS complex are all consistent with Ebstein anomaly. Pulmonic stenosis will present with a systolic ejection murmur, while tricuspid atresia and Tetralogy of Fallot will present with cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The short P-R interval with a slow upstroke of the QRS complex, as well as the grade III holosystolic murmur, suggest Ebstein anomaly. Pulmonic stenosis presents with a systolic ejection murmur, tricuspid atresia with a silent precordium, and tetralogy of Fallot with a harsh systolic murmur and a single second heart sound.
